questions.question_text: A technician is planning a network wiring installation and must ensure all cabling meets the installation requirements for air-handling spaces in the celling in case of a fire. Which of the following characteristics does plenum cabling have to meet this requirement?

discussion.content:
What is PVC cable in networking?
Polyvinyl Chloride cabling, or simply PVC, is a grade of network cabling that uses polyvinyl chloride (PVC) plastic for its outer protective insulating jacket. Polyvinyl chloride cabling is cheap and flexible but gives off dangerous gases during combustion.

sounds BAD

comments.content: comptia a+ with open space use plenum not pvc so the ans is right

questions.question_text: A network technician installs a new Layer 3 switch in the accounting office. Which of the following should the technician configure on the switch to enhance network security?

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: B
key word = to enhance network security

questions.question_text: A help desk technician is assisting a user who is experiencing issues with video conferencing when a laptop is undocked. During meetings, the audio becomes garbled, and the video sometimes pauses for brief periods. Which of the following is the MOST probable cause of these issues?

discussion.content: The question states what is the cause? The cause is the overcapacity. The symptom is latency. It also notes this happens during meetings so I assume that implies more people on the same network than not normal aka the hint overcapacity. I won't lie I chose latency until I reread the question.
when it is docked it is on the LAN and once they undock it, it turns to Wi-Fi
only reason i can think of the answer being A is because of the word " undocked", im guessing its on the WIFI network which is over the limit of users.
Network capacity is the amount of traffic that a network can handle at any given time. This includes the number of simultaneous voice calls and maximum data speeds.

questions.question_text: A network technician is configuring a new firewall for a company with the necessary access requirements to be allowed through the firewall. Which of the following should be applied as the LAST rule in the firewall?

discussion.content: The ‘implicit deny’ security stance treats everything not given specific and selective permission as suspicious. Network boundaries that follow an implicit deny concept only allow specific IP addresses and/or service ports while blocking all others.

comments.content: Yes but why is this the last rule to implement for the firewall?

discussion.content: The wording they use for these questions is very frustrating. My thoughts: A and B are correct. OTDR to test fiber cable continuity (OC-12 implies fiber cable). A loopback is essentially a physical layer test (test the ability of an interface transmit data (Tx) and receive that data back to itself (Rx). Performing a loopback at the demarc and router checks both sides of that physical connection to see if the physical ports or maybe internal electronics are faulty). As far as cleaning the cables: this is just one of their nasty wording tricks: even if the cables are dirty, we don't care ... we'd care if the *connectors* were dirty, but the choice says cables, not connectors. Sigh... this is exam is going to destroy me.

B and F
Eliminate CDE as none of these are relevant to fiber.
A - Looking for a link light seem irrelevant as the issue is packet loss not that service is unavailable. Plus the OTDR is more helpful here anyway.
B - OTDR is useful for new cable testing and certification
F - Unclean cables is a common cause of packet loss with fiber. Real world speaking, just because its new doesn't mean the provider left it free of debris and dirt.

Loopback is layer 1, and it's a reasonable step of troubleshooting the connection.

You'd naturally test the cable after deployment, especially if there were issues with it, and OC is fiber so OTDR.
Both answers are layer 1, study more.

Troubleshooting Physical Connectivity Issues
The list of faults that come under this category are:

Improper connection of cables
Router, switch or hub port is faulty or down.
Traffic overload on the link or particular interface.
Configuration issue at layer-1.
A cannot be correct there is no routers in layer 1
c-f dont make any sense. AB are the only 2 left

comments.content: Fiber cables are impervious to EMI.
But would EMI cause issues with fiber? Otherwise it would be B and F, would it not?

discussion.content: I go with E and F-------------------------Layer 1...................Physical Layer

A -> layer 2 or layer 4
B -> layer1
F -> layer 1
I go for B,F

comments.content: This is reasonable. They are both Layer 1. E would only relate to non-Fiber since it's about EMI. Nothing else seems to fit other than B and F.

discussion.content: Why nobody has pointed this one out yet? It's wrong! B is not the right answer. There are dropped packets and errors than means the link light is there. No need for loopback at the demarc because it has been determined it works OK. However there is a need for OTDR to check the integrity of the cable. Making sure the connectors are clean would be another logical step of that process. The right answer is AF.

comments.content: if its new, its not dirty.lmaoooo, love it!
I know answer is A&B, but as for “F,”“Newness” doesn’t necessarily imply “cleanness.” FYI.
Yes it's. It clearly says a "new OC-12" so you gotta know it's a fiber connection so you will use a OTDR and that if it's new it's not dirty.

questions.question_text: A telecommunications provider has just deployed a new OC-12 circuit at a customer site. While the circuit showed no errors from the provider end to the customer's demarcation point, a network administrator is trying to determine the cause of dropped packets and errors on the circuit. Which of the following should the network administrator do to rule out any problems at Layer 1? (Choose two.)

choices.F: Clean the cables to be sure they are free of dust and debris
choices.C: Use a pinout tester to validate the cable integrity
choices.E: Check for any devices that may be causing EMI on the cable
choices.B: Use an OTDR to validate the cable integrity
choices.D: Use a multimeter to validate the cable integrity
choices.A: Use a loopback at the demark and router, and check for a link light
